title: PING SPIKES
body:
My ping has been very high lately and I don't know what's causing it. It used to stay constantly at 48, now it hovers around 50 and lately has been at 300 and fluctuating around there. A temporary fix I've been using is ipconfig /flushdns in the run command.
I don't know what to do or what might be causing it.
Can someone help me out plos? I'm not a computer person so a simplified explanation would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks

replies.body:
Hey there,

Could you do the following for me;

* [Download WinMTR](https://sourceforge.net/projects/winmtr/files/WinMTR-v092.zip/download) and run a traceroute to the following IP. (Allow this to run for 5-15 minutes)
  * 103.240.227.5
* Once adequate time has passed, stop the traceroute, export your results as text.
* Run the [ICSI netalyzr](http://netalyzr.icsi.berkeley.edu/).
* Post back with a link to your WinMTR results (You can use [pastebin](http://pastebin.com/) for this) and the url to your ICSI netalyzr results.

Hey, I did the WinMTR thing and I have the results here: http://pastebin.com/RqPsRaNg  
I tried to do the ICSI netalyzr but it would get to the very end and say something like "attempting to repost test results" and my internet to the computer would stop. Every other device connected to the internet would work except for the computer (doing the test). I had to restart the router to get the internet to the computer going again.

Hey there,

There's definitely some minor packet loss occurring along the way, some of which appears to be originating from your local network.

Are you using a wired or wireless connection?
I'm using wired. From the computer to the router using an ethernet cable.

Could you please try re-running the ICSI netalyzr, however instead of using the web page could you please use their CLI application.
http://netalyzr.icsi.berkeley.edu/cli.html

I tried doing this but again my internet crashed? or something because I couldn't access the internet from my computer after attempting this. I'll try again later but I'm not sure if it'll turn out differently from how it has been
That sounds really odd, could you attempt to run the test from another computer on the same network for me, do you experience the same issue?
